quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Witchcraft and Concert
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, people, bangladesh. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: To what prominent religious group did the majority of people of Salem Village belong during the time of the notorious Salem witch trials in the 17th century?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Puritans

questions.question: Durong the Salem Witch Trials, those accused of witchcraft were burned at the stake.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: The Concert for Bangladesh was the first celebrity concert and musical project to raise money worldwide for the needy. Eric Clapton, Badfinger, Billy Preston and Ravi Shankar appeared. Bob Dylan made an unannounced appearance to play his first concert in two years. Who organized the Concert for Bangladesh?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Harrison

questions.question: Which well-known author changed his name as a result of the Salem Witch Trials?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nathaniel Hawthorn

questions.question: It was just the musical chords of E and F played alternately back and forth but even to this day
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jaws

questions.question: On April 30, 1975 Marine Master Sergeant John Valdez was the last Marine on the last helicopter out of this capital city. From what city did Master Sergeant Valdezs departure signal the last official military presence in Vietnam.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Saigon

questions.question: Witchcraft was used as the explanation for a sickness that afflicted some of the village girls in Salem. Historians now believe that the girls hallucinations may have been caused by eating moldy bread.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: First photographed by Richard Avedon, this campaign was one of the most famous and successful ad campaigns of the 70s. The ads features beautiful black and white photos of Judy Garland, Marlene Dietrich, Lauren Bacall and Barbra Streisand. What company asked the question What Becomes a Legend Most?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Blackglama

questions.question: How old was Giles Cory when he was pressed to death?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 81

questions.question: Death Hill was the name of the sight of execution during the Salem witch trials.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Who was the first man to be accused of witchcraft?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Proctor

questions.question: Dorothy Good, who was the youngest person to be accused of witchcraft, was how old?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 4

questions.question: In what was billed as the Battle of the Sexes, tennis champ Billie Jean King didnt show any love as she won this match in straight sets. Who did Billie Jean King beat to win the Battle of the Sexes?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bobby Riggs

questions.question: How many people were murdered as a result of the Salem Witch Trials?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 20

questions.question: On February 28, 1983 a record 105.9 million viewers tuned in to watch the last show of this programs eleven-year run.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: MASH

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Ship and Shore
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, john, ship. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: In a shipwreck known as this, a Chinese merchant ship carrying  porcelain sank near an island in South Male Atoll In the 16th century.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Guraidhoo Wreck

questions.question: On July 19, 1545 King Henry VIII prepared to watch the new pride of his fleet sail out to engage the French.  However, he ended up watching a disaster as this heavy ship heeled over and rapidly capsized when water poured into the lower gun ports.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mary Rose

questions.question: During a hot night in  August 1658, this ship was wrecked on Maamakunudhoo Atoll, while en route to Bengal. There was a small treasure onboard this ship: eight chests of silver and gold from West Africa.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Persia Merchant

questions.question: On November 8, 1843 this ship left Lisbon, Portugal, with 84 convicts and headed for Goa, India. Near Cape of Good Hope the ship was taken by a strong current and was driven too close to the shore. She then struck the reef off Muli Island in Mulaku Atoll.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Prazer e Allegria

questions.question: The First Triumvirate is the name historians give to the unofficial political alliance between what three man?

options.text: Marcus Licinius Crassus, Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus and Gaius Julius Caesar
Gaius Julius Caesar, Anthony and Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus
Octavius, Lepidus and Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Marcus Licinius Crassus, Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus and Gaius Julius Caesar

questions.question: Li Ka Shing, a Hong Kong businessman and one of the worlds richest men, paid an extremely large ransom for the safe return of his son, Victor Li Tzar. How much did he pay?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 134,000,000.00

questions.question: John Walsh, host of Americas Most Wanted, is the father of kidnapped and murdered six-year-old, Adam Walsh.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Which temperature scale came first, Fahrenheit or Celsius?

options.text: They were developed at  the same time
They were developed so close together that no one knows

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fahrenheit

questions.question: The son of this famous singer was kidnapped on December 8, 1963 at Harrahs Lake Tahoe.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Frank Sinatra

questions.question: Said unsinkable, this ship started her maiden voyage with 2,220 passengers aboard in 1912. Unfortunately this was her first and her last voyage - she hit an iceberg and sank.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Titanic

questions.question: On July 30, 1865 along the beaches of California, off Crescent City, a summer storm developed and this ship came across a submerged pinnacle known as The Dragons Teeth.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Brother Jonathan

questions.question: On May 7th, 1915 this famous ship was hit by a torpedo near the shore of Queenstown, Ireland. It sank in 15 minutes.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lusitania

questions.question: This vessel sunk in lake Michigan in 1919, after a fire on board got out of control.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Frank OConnor

questions.question: On May 2 1982,  the British nuclear submarine HMS Conqueror fired two torpedoes at the Argentine warship.  323 men of the 1,093 crew were killed on impact.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: General Belgrano

questions.question: Two years after Titanics tragic sinking - In the summer of 1914 - this ship started a journey from Quebec harbor to England.  A heavy fog hid the horizon and she was hit by the Storstad, a Norwegian collier. Only 465 of the 1500 people onboard survived.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Empress of Ireland

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Year and Engineer
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, colonies, combustion. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This engineer, architect and industrialist invented the rotary lathe, used in plywood manufacturing.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Immanuel Nobel

questions.question: Samuel Colt patented his revolver in this year, and later built the first industrialized firearm factory.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1835

questions.question: The first Balfour Declaration, UKs committment to the establishment of a Jewish national home was issued in what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1917

questions.question: The first photograph is considered to be an image produced by the French inventor Nicéphore Niépce, in what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1826

questions.question: What product was registered with the United States Patent and Trademark Office on October 27 in 1970, by the Van Brode Milling Company?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Spork

questions.question: Having been forgotten on the Treaty of Versailles and remaining legally at war, this country signed an official treaty with Germany, thus officially ending WW I .
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Andorra

questions.question: This engineer, sometimes called The Father of Cool, invented the modern air conditioning system, soon after he graduated from Cornell University in 1901.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Willis Carrier

questions.question: In what year was slavery banned in the British colonies?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1833

questions.question: What object, often regarded as a symbol of American consumerism, was designed in 1957 by Don Featherstone, who was later awarded the Ig Nobel Prize, a parody of the Nobel Prize?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The pink flamingo lawn ornament

questions.question: When was the first internal combustion engine to run on a mixture of explosive gas and air designed?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1859

questions.question: This tool was originally made in Germany, but in 1896, after 5 years of hard work, Karl Elsener doubled its features.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Swiss army knife

questions.question: What device was invented in 1879 by James Ritty, the owner of a tavern in Dayton, Ohio?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The cash register

questions.question: Peter Lymburner Robertson received a patent in 1909 for the invention of what tool?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The square-headed screwdriver

questions.question: She was the first African American woman to get a patent. It was issued on July 14, 1885, for a cabinet bed.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sarah Goode

questions.question: Although it had been around for a long time, it was not until this person used chloroform, that it became a popular anesthetic.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Queen Victoria

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Stonewall Jackson and General Stonewall Jackson
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, therapist, graduate. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Stonewall Jackson was wounded by his own men at which battle?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chancellorsville

questions.question: What was the real name of General Stonewall Jackson?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Jonathan Jackson

questions.question: During the early months of 1862, General Stonewall Jackson led a successful campaign in which region?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Shenandoah Valley

questions.question: General Stonewall Jackson was a graduate of the Virginia Military Institute.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Which general gave Stonewall Jackson his nickname?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Barnard E. Bee

questions.question: Where was Stonewall Jacksons body buried?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lexington, VA

questions.question: He was the inventor of condensed milk. In 1874 he died in Texas, in a county which was posthumously named after him.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gail Borden

questions.question: This American woman, who worked as a physical therapist, invented a device that could be used by veteran soldiers, who had lost their arms. It was an electrical apparatus that could deliver food through a tube.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bessie Blount Griffin

questions.question: Before the Civil War, Stonewall Jackson  was a professor of artillery and natural philosophy at which institute of higher learning?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Virginia Military Institute

questions.question: Homer set his epics in the last phase of the Bronze Age in ancient Greece. What is this phase called?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mycenaean Greece

questions.question: The first evidence of human existence in Europe dates back to approximately how many years ago?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 35 000

questions.question: Alexander the Great is a son of this European ruler.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Philip II

questions.question: General Jackson acquired his nickname of Stonewall at which Civil War battle?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bull Run

questions.question: Stonewall Jacksons mortal wound necessitated the amputation of which limb?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: left arm

questions.question: General Stonewall Jackson did not participate at which of these battles?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gettysburg

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Country and Event
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, diseases, ship. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: In the early 1950s, which of the following became the third country to have an atomic bomb?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: England

questions.question: Which event did not occur in the 1950s?

options.text: Bobby Fisher becomes the World Champion in chess.
The Frisbee is successfully marketed in the USA.
The first successful test of a hydrogen bomb was done at Enewetak

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bobby Fisher becomes the World Champion in chess.

questions.question: The First Triumvirate was a secret pact in Ancient Rome aimed at controlling the Republic. It was formed in the mid-1st century BC by three great men - Pompey, Crassus, and who else?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Julius Caesar

questions.question: In the 1958 NFL Championship Game, the Colts played against the Giants. Which statement is untrue about the game?

options.text: The game was the first NFL Championship to go into sudden-death overtime.
Mel Triplett scored a 1 yard TD run.
The Giants quarterback, Y.A.Tittle, threw a TD pass to Frank Gifford for the Giants first score.
The game was won by the Baltimore Colts on a 2 yard run by Alan Ameche.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Giants quarterback, Y.A.Tittle, threw a TD pass to Frank Gifford for the Giants first score.

questions.question: Which event did not occur in the same year as the other three?

options.text: UNIVAC becomes the first mass-produced computer.
Theodore Geisel writes Cat in the Hat.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Theodore Geisel writes Cat in the Hat.

questions.question: The Roman empire was revived when Pope Leo III crowned a king of the Franks as Imperator Augustus on 25 December 800. Under what name is this king known?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Charlemagne

questions.question: What did Joseph Woodland and  Bernard Silver patent in 1952?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: the barcode

questions.question: In 1957 Jimmy Hoffa became president of which union?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: International Brotherhood of Teamsters

questions.question: Under what ruler was Christianity officially acknowledged in the Roman Empire?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Constantine I

questions.question: Who started the movement of Protestant Reformation in Europe?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Martin Luther

questions.question: In 395 the Roman Empire was divided into two: the Western Roman Empire centered around Ravenna, and the Eastern Roman Empire centered around Constantinople. Who was the last emperor of a united Roman Empire?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Theodosius I

questions.question: Which US space ship discovered the Van Allen Radiation Belt in 1958?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Explorer I

questions.question: What was Elvis Presleys first motion picture?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Love Me Tender

questions.question: The Black Death, one of the deadliest infectious diseases in history,  took the lives of between 25-50 million people in Europe. What writer depicts the lives of people at that time?

options.text: Erasmus in In Praise of Folly

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Giovanni Boccaccio in The Decameron

questions.question: In what country did the Industrial Revolution start?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Great Britain

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Civilization and Alphabet
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, country, harappan. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What was the first civilization to make use of the alphabet that is believed to be the ancestor of all modern alphabets?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Phoenicia

questions.question: The country of Russia was named for the Vikings.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What society, that inhabited southern Mesopotamia, is widely regarded as the earliest civilization on Earth?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sumer

questions.question: The Vikings adopted Christianity around 1000 AD.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: The Rosetta stone helped scientists to decipher the alphabet of this ancient civilization.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ancient Egypt

questions.question: On what Mediterranean island did the Minoan civilization arise?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Crete

questions.question: What was the predominating religion in the Achaemenid Empire, one of the first Persian empires?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Zoroastrianism

questions.question: According to legend, Ancient Rome was founded by the brothers Romulus and Remus who were raised by what animal?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wolf

questions.question: Which one of these was not part of the Million Dollar Quartet, formed in 1956 by Sun Records?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Willie Nelson

questions.question: Four colossal statues guard the temple Abu Simbel of what Egyptian pharaoh?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ramesses II

questions.question: Which was the largest empire in pre-Columbian America?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Inca

questions.question: On which show did Elvis Presley make his first TV appearance?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Dorsey Brothers Stage Show

questions.question: The Boston Celtics were the dominant professional basketball team in the 1950s. Which one of these  never played for the Celtics in the 1950s?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Walter Dukes

questions.question: This civilization arose in Central Mexico and its members spoke the Nahuatl language .
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Aztec

questions.question: Harappan was the mature phase of this civilization that flourished in the river valleys in Sindh province of Pakistan, extending westward into Balochistan province, and in West India.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Indus Valley Civilization
